# List of most expensive paintings

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne_222.jpg/220px-
Paul_C%C3%A9zanne_222.jpg)](/wiki/File:Paul_C%C3%A9zanne_222.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Paul_C%C3%A9zanne_222.jpg "Enlarge")

_[The Card Players](/wiki/The_Card_Players "The Card Players")_ by [Paul
Cézanne](/wiki/Paul_C%C3%A9zanne "Paul Cézanne")

This is a list of the **highest known prices paid
for[paintings](/wiki/Painting "Painting")**. The earliest sale on the list
(_[Vase with Fifteen Sunflowers](/wiki/Sunflowers_\(Van_Gogh_series\)
"Sunflowers \(Van Gogh series\)")_ by [Vincent van
Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh")) is from 1987, and more than
tripled the previous record price, set only two years before, introducing a
new era in top picture prices. The sale was also significant in that for the
first time a "modern" painting (in this case from 1888) became the record
holder, as opposed to the [old master paintings](/wiki/Old_master_painting
"Old master painting") which had always previously held it. The current record
price is approximately [$](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States
dollar")450 million paid for [Leonardo Da Vinci's](/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci
"Leonardo da Vinci") [_Salvator Mundi_](/wiki/Salvator_Mundi_\(Leonardo\)
"Salvator Mundi \(Leonardo\)") in November 2017.

##
Background[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_most_expensive_paintings&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Background")]

The world's most famous paintings, especially old master works done before
1803, are generally owned or held at [museums](/wiki/Museum "Museum"), for
viewing by patrons. The museums very rarely sell them, and as such, they are
quite literally priceless. _[Guinness World
Records](/wiki/Guinness_World_Records "Guinness World Records")_ lists the
_[Mona Lisa](/wiki/Mona_Lisa "Mona Lisa")_ as having the highest
[insurance](/wiki/Insurance "Insurance") value for a painting in history. On
permanent display at [The Louvre](/wiki/The_Louvre "The Louvre") museum in
Paris, the _Mona Lisa_ was assessed at US$100 million on December 14, 1962.
Taking [inflation](/wiki/Inflation "Inflation") into account, the 1962 value
would be around US$790 million in 2016.[1]

The earliest sale on the list below (_[Vase with Fifteen
Sunflowers](/wiki/Sunflowers_\(series_of_paintings\) "Sunflowers \(series of
paintings\)")_ by [Vincent van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van
Gogh")) is from March 1987; with a price of £24.75 million (£63.9 million in
current value) it tripled the previous record and introduced a new era in top
art sales. Before this, the highest absolute price paid for a painting was
£8.1 million (£18.0 million in current value) paid by the [J. Paul Getty
Museum](/wiki/J._Paul_Getty_Museum "J. Paul Getty Museum") for
[Mantegna](/wiki/Andrea_Mantegna "Andrea Mantegna")'s _[Adoration of the
Magi](/wiki/Adoration_of_the_Magi_\(Mantegna\) "Adoration of the Magi
\(Mantegna\)")_ at [Christie's](/wiki/Christie%27s "Christie's") in London on
April 18, 1985.[2] In [constant dollars](/wiki/Constant_dollars "Constant
dollars"), the highest price paid before 1987 was by the [National Gallery of
Art](/wiki/National_Gallery_of_Art "National Gallery of Art") when in February
1967 they acquired [Leonardo da Vinci](/wiki/Leonardo_da_Vinci "Leonardo da
Vinci")'s _[Ginevra de' Benci](/wiki/Ginevra_de%27_Benci "Ginevra de' Benci")_
for around $5 million ($36 million in current dollars) from the [Princely
Family of Liechtenstein](/wiki/Princely_Family_of_Liechtenstein "Princely
Family of Liechtenstein"). The sale of Van Gogh's _Sunflowers_ was also
significant in that for the first time a "modern" (in this case 1888) painting
became the record holder, as opposed to the [old master
paintings](/wiki/Old_master_painting "Old master painting") which previously
had dominated the market. In contrast, there are currently only nine pre-1875
paintings among the listed top 79, and no works painted between 1635 and 1874.

An exceptional case is graffiti artist [David Choe](/wiki/David_Choe "David
Choe"), who accepted payment in shares for painting graffiti art in the
headquarters of a fledgling [Facebook](/wiki/Facebook "Facebook"). While his
shares were of limited value when he was awarded them, by the time of
Facebook's [IPO](/wiki/IPO "IPO") they were valued at around $200m.[3]

## Van Gogh, Picasso, and
Warhol[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_most_expensive_paintings&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Van Gogh, Picasso, and Warhol")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/35/Red_vineyards.jpg/220px-
Red_vineyards.jpg)](/wiki/File:Red_vineyards.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Red_vineyards.jpg "Enlarge")

_[The Red Vineyard](/wiki/The_Red_Vineyard "The Red Vineyard")_ , the only
painting [Vincent van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh") sold
during his lifetime.

[Vincent van Gogh](/wiki/Vincent_van_Gogh "Vincent van Gogh"), [Pablo
Picasso](/wiki/Pablo_Picasso "Pablo Picasso"), and [Andy
Warhol](/wiki/Andy_Warhol "Andy Warhol") are by far the best represented
artists in the list. Whereas Picasso and Warhol became wealthy men, Van Gogh
(supposedly) sold only one painting in his lifetime, _[The Red
Vineyard](/wiki/The_Red_Vineyard "The Red Vineyard")_ , for 400 francs (about
$2000 in 2017) to the impressionist painter and heiress [Anna
Boch](/wiki/Anna_Boch "Anna Boch").[4] His seven paintings in the list below
alone were sold for over 730 million current dollars.

"Consumer price index") inflation-adjusted value (**in bold**) in millions of
[United States dollars](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United States dollar") in
the current year.[note 1] Where necessary, the price is first converted to
dollars using the [exchange rate](/wiki/Exchange_rate "Exchange rate") at the
time the painting was sold. The inflation adjustment may change as recent
inflation rates are often revised. A list in another currency may be in a
slightly different order due to exchange rate fluctuations. Paintings are only
listed once, i.e. for the highest price sold.

Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=List_of_most_expensive_paintings&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** The wikipedia template uses a yearly average inflation. Using monthly averages gives slightly different numbers, most significantly for paintings sold early or late in a year with significant inflation.
  2. **Jump up ^** Exact price (even the currency of sale) is not known, with estimates from $250 million to even $300 million
  3. **Jump up ^** Reportedly, Gachet's portrait was privately resold to a European buyer in 1997 or 1998 for $65-$90 million through Sotheby’s[25][26]
  4. **Jump up ^** The triptych had probably been reassembled by the Italian collector Francesco De Simone Niquesa, but were resold to a person in the US before 2013[28][29]
  5. **Jump up ^** This is the small version of the painting; the large version is at [Musée d'Orsay](/wiki/Mus%C3%A9e_d%27Orsay "Musée d'Orsay").
  6. **Jump up ^** Privately resold for ca. $50 million through Sotheby’s in 1997.[26]
  7. **Jump up ^** One of two pastel versions; another two painted versions (and lithography) exist, all created by Munch
  8. **Jump up ^** Most expensive painting by a living artist
  9. **Jump up ^** The paintings transferred to the dealers include a late [Monet](/wiki/Monet "Monet") entitled _Corona (Water Lilies)_ from around 1920; [Renoir](/wiki/Renoir "Renoir")'s _Reclining Nude_ of 1902, [Kandinsky](/wiki/Wassily_Kandinsky "Wassily Kandinsky")'s _Autumn Landscape, Murnau_ from 1908, and [Picasso](/wiki/Picasso "Picasso")'s _Striped Bodice_ from September 1943.
  10. **Jump up ^** Alan Bond could not pay off the painting, and _Irises_ was resold (probably for somewhat less) to the Getty Museum.
  11. **Jump up ^** Price excludes sales commission and other costs.
  12. **Jump up ^** exact date of sale is not available
  13. **Jump up ^** Later in 2002, Thomson donated his private collection, including the Rubens, to the [Art Gallery of Ontario](/wiki/Art_Gallery_of_Ontario "Art Gallery of Ontario")[53]
  14. **Jump up ^** Annenberg donated it subsequently to the [Metropolitan Museum of Art](/wiki/Metropolitan_Museum_of_Art "Metropolitan Museum of Art")
  15. **Jump up ^** Steve Wynn, who bid on the painting at auction, privately acquired the work several months later from the unidentified buyer for an undisclosed, supposedly lower price. Kenneth Griffin acquired it in 2004 from Wynn.[64]
  16. **Jump up ^** Usually estimated at "over €50 M" or "between 50 and 60 million Euros". $75M would have been €53M on July 12, 2011.
  17. **Jump up ^** resold for £12m to Stavros Niarchos in 1993
  18. **Jump up ^** A Belgian banker and collector who bought it in 1939 for $18,000. His was the last name on the 1988 provenance list; painting came from "a private collection in Arizona"
  19. **Jump up ^** Son of Daniel (conductor & cellist) and Eleanore Saidenberg who were Picasso's New York dealers from 1955 to 1973.[87]
  20. **Jump up ^** On Oct. 7, 2005, The New York Times reported that Steven Cohen bought van Gogh's "Peasant Woman Against a Background of Wheat" and [Gauguin](/wiki/Paul_Gauguin "Paul Gauguin")'s "[Bathers](/wiki/File:Paul_Gauguin_-_A_Walk_by_the_Sea_or_Tahitian_Family_1902.jpg "File:Paul Gauguin - A Walk by the Sea or Tahitian Family 1902.jpg")" (1903) from Steve Wynn for approximately $110 million,[89] though guesses range from $100-150 million. One or both of the paintings may thus occur higher on this list.
